Which is why I struggled with the yellow board the most, as that strategy would not work.
Did visible ones help or hinder?: They hindered me on the yellow board. The last board was the easiest, so I would say they hindered me overall more than actually helping me.
Anything else: I enjoyed my experience, I can't think of anything right now that could have improved my participation. Thank you.

Notice schema_IC: I noticed that on a board or two the locations changed but can't remember which colour was that board.
Notice landmarks: Not particularly so that I can name what was moved and what was fixed
Strategy?: I was trying to learn the location with respect to the size of the board. I was trying to divide the board in half and draw some imaginary lines and compare with respect to those that was my main strategy. Initially I was trying to use other pictures, in the first few boards I was trying to use the location of the visible pictures as cue, but that seemed harder with the visible pictures changing and their location changing as well. So I changed strategy and decided to learn the locations with respect to the middle of the board (horizontally and vertically) and this was easier.
Did visible ones help or hinder?: Hinder me, didn't like them very much, the board that didn't have the visible pictures (I think it was the purple board) was the easiest/best. Shame my PC froze for a second and I missed some of the trials on that board.
Anything else: The location was extremely sensitive, I hope you calculate the distance from where I clicked to where the object was rather than the correct and incorrect feedbacks. Probably more than 90% of the time I was clicking very very close, some of which I might have missed by a single pixel, seriously, it was too sensitive to the exact location of the items.
